  "article_text": [
    "in 1980 culler and shalen introduced in @xcite an algebraic set in a complex space for a finitely presented group @xmath1 , now known as the character variety of @xmath1 . the framework of character varieties has been giving powerful tools and is now playing important roles in geometry and topology . on the other hand , it is not easy to calculate character varieties and thus to investigate the geometric structures in general , though an underlying idea of character varieties is simple as follows .",
    "let @xmath1 be a finitely presented group generated by @xmath2 elements @xmath3 .",
    "for a representation @xmath4 , the character @xmath5 of @xmath6 is the function on @xmath1 defined by @xmath7 ( @xmath8 ) . throughout this paper , we simply denote by @xmath9 the trace @xmath10 for an unspecified representation @xmath4 .",
    "we sometimes omit the brackets in the trace like @xmath11 for simplicity . by @xcite ( see also @xcite ) , _ the @xmath12-trace identity _",
    "@xmath13 shows that @xmath9 is expressed by a polynomial in @xmath14 , @xmath15 and @xmath16 , for any @xmath17 .",
    "then the character variety of @xmath1 , denoted by @xmath18 , is constructed basically by the image of the set of characters @xmath19 of @xmath12-representations of @xmath1 under the map is not injective , however , for the characters of irreducible representations it is injective .",
    "refer to @xcite . ]",
    "@xmath20 the resulting set turns out to be a closed algebraic set ( refer to @xcite ) . by definition ,",
    "this algebraic set depends on a choice of generators of @xmath1 ( the coordinates of @xmath18 vary if we change the choice of generating set of @xmath1 ) , however , the geometric structures do not depend on that choice .",
    "so @xmath18 is an invariant of @xmath1 up to _ isomorphism of algebraic sets_. here two algebraic sets @xmath21 and",
    "@xmath22 in a complex space @xmath23 are said to be isomorphic or _",
    "bipolynomial _ if there exist polynomial maps @xmath24 and @xmath25 such that @xmath26 , @xmath27",
    ". then @xmath28 and @xmath29 are called isomorphisms or bipolynomial maps .    as far as the authors know , there exist few discussions on isomorphic transformations of character varieties . in this paper ,",
    "we first give two polynomial maps giving isomorphisms between character varieties of a group @xmath1 coming from two different choices of generating sets , especially in the case where @xmath1 is the fundamental group of a 3-manifold associated to _ a knot _ in 3-sphere as follows .",
    "let @xmath30 denote a 3-sphere .",
    "for a knot @xmath31 in @xmath30 , which is an embedding of a circle @xmath32 in @xmath30 , we denote by @xmath33 the knot group of @xmath31 , i.e. , the fundamental group of the knot complement @xmath34 .",
    "for example , there exist knots parametrized by sequences of integers @xmath35 $ ] associated to the number of _ twists _ , called _ 2-bridge knots_. ( see figure [ 2-bridge_knots ] . for more details , refer to @xcite . )",
    "the knot @xmath36 $ ] depicted in figure [ twist_knots ] is a type of 2-bridge knots , called the _",
    "@xmath37-twist knot_. sometimes the sequence @xmath35 $ ] is encoded in a rational number @xmath38 @xmath39 by the following continuous fraction : @xmath40 then we denote by @xmath41 the 2-bridge knot with a rational number expression @xmath38 .",
    "it is shown that @xmath42 and @xmath43 are coprime odd integers ( refer to @xcite ) .",
    "@xmath44= \\begin{minipage}{10cm}\\includegraphics[width=\\hsize]{2-bridge.eps}\\end{minipage}\\ ] ]    by _",
    "wirtinger s algorithm _ and reduction of generators , we have the following presentation of the knot group @xmath45 : @xmath46 where @xmath47 are _ meridians _ shown in figure [ 2-bridge_knots ] , @xmath48 and @xmath49 . here",
    "@xmath50 denotes the maximal integer @xmath37 satisfying @xmath51 . by @xcite , the character variety @xmath52 is given as the algebraic set defined by @xmath53 for example , this equation induces the following presentation of the character variety @xmath54 of the @xmath55-twist knot @xmath56 .",
    "let @xmath57 be the chebyshev polynomial of the second kind , i.e. , for any integer @xmath2 , @xmath58 note that @xmath59 holds for any integer @xmath2 .",
    "we denote by @xmath60 the polynomial in the complex polynomial ring @xmath61 $ ] defined by @xmath62 where @xmath63 .",
    "using @xmath60 , we can describe the character variety @xmath64 as the algebraic set @xmath65 where @xmath66 and @xmath67 .",
    "( see subsection [ subsec_km ] for details . for @xmath68 , refer to subsection [ subsec_k_odd ] . )",
    "@xmath69=\\begin{minipage}{7cm}\\includegraphics[width=\\hsize]{k - m.eps}\\end{minipage}.\\ ] ]    on the other hand , we can also calculate the character variety using _ the kauffman bracket skein module_.     "for any integer @xmath37 , let @xmath71 be the polynomial in @xmath61 $ ] defined by @xmath72 and let @xmath73 be the second factor of @xmath71 .",
    "then the character variety @xmath74 is also described as the algebraic set @xmath75 where @xmath76 and @xmath77 ( refer to @xcite ) . by definition , the algebraic sets in and at @xmath78 must be isomorphic as algebraic sets . in subsection [ subsec_km ] , we construct bipolynomial maps which give isomorphisms between and at @xmath78 .    actually , the presentation in of @xmath74 is more useful than to discuss a geometric property of @xmath18 , that is , the number of irreducible components .",
    "for example , the presentation of @xmath74 immediately shows the following result .",
    "[ main_thm ] for any positive integer ( @xmath79 ) , taking the mirror image of @xmath80 and arranging it , we can obtain @xmath81 and thus a similar result to theorem [ main_thm ] . in that case , @xmath82 will shift to @xmath83 . ]",
    "@xmath37 , the polynomial @xmath84 is irreducible in @xmath61 $ ] .",
    "therefore , @xmath74 consists of two irreducible components .",
    "indeed , as in @xcite the factor @xmath73 @xmath85 can not be factorized as @xmath86 where @xmath87 $ ] .",
    "moreover , @xmath88 where @xmath87 $ ] can not occur either as a factorization of @xmath89 , since @xmath90 and @xmath91 are relatively prime in @xmath92 $ ] .",
    "hence @xmath73 is irreducible in @xmath61 $ ] and this completes the proof of theorem [ main_thm ] .",
    "it was studied in @xcite that the character variety of most _ double twist knots _ , including twist knots , consists of two irreducible components , however , they used the genera of algebraic varieties to show the fact .",
    "our proof of theorem [ main_thm ] shown above uses only basic calculations on the chebyshev polynomials @xmath57 .",
    "this is an efficiency of chebyshev polynomials .",
    "in fact , the method used in the proof of theorem [ main_thm ] can be applied to another type of 2-bridge knots denoted by @xmath93 , which was considered in @xcite .",
    "then that gives the following theorem using basic calculations .",
    "[ thm_bp3 ] the character variety @xmath94 consists of exactly two irreducible components .",
    "this paper mainly shows    * presentations of the character varieties of 2-bridge knots @xmath95 and @xmath93 using the chebyshev polynomials @xmath57 , including the transformations between the algebraic sets in and , * an elementary proof of theorem [ thm_bp3 ] using chebyshev polynomials .",
    "these recover the results of burde on the irreducibility of non - abelian @xmath0-representation spaces in @xcite .",
    "moreover , they can be applied to determine some minimal elements of a partial ordering of prime knots ( see section [ sec_appli ] ) .",

    "the difference between the presentations in and or and is the method to calculate the character varieties . as seen in subsections [ subsec_km ] and [ subsec_k_odd ] , the presentations and are calculated along the definition using the trace functions of representations . on the other hand ,",
    "the presentation in is calculated by using the kauffman bracket skein algebra . ]",
    "( kbsa for short ) .",
    "the kbsa of a 3-manifold is the quotient of the module over @xmath178 generated by all free homotopy classes of loops in @xmath179 by _ the kauffman bracket skein relations _ : @xmath180{skein - rel.eps}\\end{minipage},\\   \\begin{minipage}{2cm}\\includegraphics[width=\\hsize]{circ.eps}\\end{minipage } = -2,\\ ] ] where in the first relation loops coincide each other outside dashed circles ( refer to @xcite ) . by the result of @xcite or @xcite ,",
    "a loop @xmath121 can be considered as @xmath181 and _ the kauffman bracket skein relations _ can be thought of as the @xmath12-trace identities .",
    "this correspondence gives a method to calculate character varieties using the kauffman bracket skein theory .    from the kbsa point of view",
    ", we can take two free homotopy classes of loops represented by @xmath182 and @xmath183 as the generators of the kbsa of @xmath184 ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 1 ) ) .",
    "these give the parameters @xmath76 and @xmath185 of the presentation in and thus @xmath74 .",
    "if we want to transform the algebraic set in or to , we need to express the parameters @xmath66 and @xmath186 in or as polynomials in @xmath187 and @xmath188 . the parameter @xmath189 is exactly @xmath190 . on the other hand",

    "( see @xcite .",
    "note that the loop @xmath110 defined in @xcite is actually the mirror image of the above @xmath193 , however , the recursion relation does not change under the mirror image . )",

    "we will need the following result , which is a generalization of the method used in @xcite and the proof of theorem [ main_thm ] , in order to show the irreducibility of @xmath218 over @xmath178 in the case of @xmath93 .",

    "theorem [ main_thm ] determines some minimal elements for a partial order on the set of prime knots in @xmath30 defined as follows ( refer to @xcite for example ) .",
    "let @xmath31 and @xmath330 be prime knots in @xmath30 which are _ non - trivial _",
    ", i.e. , they do not bound embedded disks in @xmath30",
    ". then we write @xmath331 if there exists an epimorphism ( a surjective group homomorphism ) from @xmath33 onto @xmath332 .",
    "this defines a partial order on the set of prime knots .",
    "we can apply the following theorem to the partial order @xmath333 .",
    "[ thm - bbrw ] suppose @xmath334 is a hyperbolic knot in @xmath30 such that @xmath335 of @xmath31 has only one irreducible component that contains the characters of irreducible representations",
    ". then @xmath33 does not surject onto the knot group of any other non - trivial knot .",
    "we remark that corollary 1.3 in @xcite and corollary 7.1 in @xcite also give the following ( compare to theorem [ thm - bbrw ] ) .",
    "[ thm - ors ] let @xmath31 be a hyperbolic @xmath267-bridge knot , @xmath330 a non - trivial knot .",
    "suppose there exists an epimorphism @xmath336 .",
    "then @xmath330 is a @xmath267-bridge knot and furthermore @xmath335 has more than one irreducible components containing the characters of irreducible representations .",
    "since any twist knot is a 2-bridge knot , combining theorems [ main_thm ] and [ thm - bbrw ] ( or theorem @xmath337 ) , we obtain the following corollary .",
    "[ cor_minimal ] for any integer @xmath338 , at which the @xmath37-twist knot @xmath95 is non - trivial , @xmath95 is a minimal element for the partial order @xmath333 .",
    "note that corollary [ cor_minimal ] was shown by kitano and suzuki @xcite in the case of @xmath339 , which is the trefoil knot ( i.e. , non - hyperbolic ) and to which we can not apply theorems [ thm - bbrw ] and [ thm - ors ]",
    ".    we can also apply theorems [ thm_bp3 ] and [ thm - bbrw ] to get the following .",
    "[ cor_bp3 ] for any odd integer @xmath340 satisfying @xmath263 , where @xmath93 is hyperbolic , @xmath93 is a minimal element for the partial order @xmath333 .",
    "corollaries [ cor_minimal ] and [ cor_bp3 ] also show the minimality of twist knots @xmath95 ( @xmath341 ) and the 2-bridge knots @xmath93 with respect to the partial order introduced by silver and whitten @xcite ( see also @xcite ) .",
    "the first author has been partially supported by mext kakenhi for young scientists ( b ) grant number 22740048 .",
    "the second author would like to thank t.t.q .",
    "le for helpful discussions .",
    "le : _ varieties of representations and their subvarieties of cohomology jumps for knot groups _ , ( russian ) mat .",
    "* 184 * ( 1993 ) , 57 - 82 ; translation in russian acad .",
    "sb . math .",
    "* 78 * ( 1994 ) , 187 - 209 .",
    "w. neumann and a. reid : _ arithmetic of hyperbolic manifolds _ , in topology 90 , contrib .",
    "semester low dimensional topol .",
    "1990 , ohio state university mathematics research institute publications * 1 * ( 1992 ) , 273310 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in this paper , we use chebyshev polynomials to give presentations of the character varieties of certain types of 2-bridge knots . </S>",
    "<S> this gives us an elementary method using basic calculations to discuss the number of irreducible components of the character varieties and thus to recover the results of burde on the irreducibility of non - abelian @xmath0-representation spaces in @xcite . </S>",
    "<S> these results can be applied to determine some minimal elements of a partial ordering of prime knots . </S>"
  ]
}
